artist: Utagawa Kunisada; Utagawa Hiroshige; Publisher: Maruya Kyūshirō; Carver: Yokogawa Takejirō
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
markings: date seal: 寅七 {tora nana} (Tiger 7) | censor seal:  改 {aratame} (inspected) | publisher's seal: {Maruya Kyūshirō} | carver's seal: {Yokogawa hori Take}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e), ink and color on paper
portfolio: Fifty-three Stations by Two Brushes (Sōhitsu gojūsan tsugi 雙筆五十三次)
signed: in toshidama cartouche: 豊國画 {Toyokuni ga} |  廣重画 {Hiroshige ga}
text: This print shows a young woman wearing a light, single-layer cotton robe, or yukata, a popular garment for summer. She is a traveler along the Tōkaidō, the most important road in Japan that connected Edo (today’s Tokyo) with Kyoto. She chats with a woman selling souvenirs after taking a bath. A bold pattern of chrysanthemums adorns this yukata. Its uneven edges are the printmaker’s visual shorthand for the tiny circles created by tie-dyeing, used to construct larger patterns.
title: Odawara
